questions.text:
A 56-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with right ring finger pain. The patient recalls that the right ring finger has been “catching and locking” for weeks. The symptoms seem to improve throughout the day, with gradual “unlocking” as the day progresses. Past medical history is notable for type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension, for which he takes metformin and hydrochlorothiazide. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates the fourth digit of the right hand to be in a flexed position, as shown below. Passive extension of the digit is met with some resistance. There are no palpable nodules or tenderness along the flexor tendon sheath. Nonetheless, he can fully extend the digit with minimal pain. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?  


Image reproduced from Wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient has intermittent locking and catching of the fourth digit and difficulty extending the finger from a flexed position. This clinical presentation is most consistent with trigger finger, also termed stenosing tenosynovitis.

Trigger finger is a flexor tendon that catches when it attempts to glide through a stenotic sheath, resulting in an inability to flex or extend the finger smoothly. The underlying pathology of this disease remains unclear but is thought to be due to fibrocartilaginous metaplasia of the ligamentous layer of the tendon sheath. The majority of cases are idiopathic, although some are associated with repetitive hand motions, often from occupational activities.

Clinically, patients experience a catching and locking sensation of the finger that progressively worsens over time. Patients may also experience pain localized over the volar aspect of the metacarpophalangeal joint.  

Treatment is primarily conservative and involves splinting, analgesia, and rest. Local glucocorticoid injection can also be administered. Patients who are refractory to conservative management or glucocorticoid injections may warrant the surgical release of the flexor tendon.  

Option Analysis

✅ Stenosing tenosynovitis  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Dupuytren contracture  :
Incorrect: A Dupuytren contracture is characterized by slow, progressive fibroproliferation of the palmar fascia. Patients typically have a palpable cord or nodules along the flexor tendon sheath.  
❌ Flexor tenosynovitis  :
Incorrect: Flexor tenosynovitis is a surgical emergency and refers to a deep space infection of the flexor tendon sheath. Patients can present with pain with passive extension, tenderness over the entire length of the flexor tendon sheath, symmetric finger swelling along the length of the tendon sheath, and flexed posture of the affected finger.
❌ Mallet finger  :
Incorrect: Mallet finger refers to an injury to the extensor digitorum as it crosses the distal interphalangeal joint. This injury results in an inability to extend the finger at the distal interphalangeal joint.  
❌ Jersey finger  :
Incorrect: Jersey finger refers to an injury to the flexor digitorum profundus tendon as it crosses the distal interphalangeal joint. This injury results in an inability to flex the finger at the distal interphalangeal joint.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician to evaluate bilateral wrist pain. The patient has worse pain at night and is associated with paresthesias of the first, second, third, and half of the fourth finger. She states, “I need to figure out what is going on. I can barely sleep at night.” Past medical history includes hypertension, type II diabetes mellitus, rheumatoid arthritis, and obesity. She smokes a pack of cigarettes daily and drinks two to three beers nightly. She currently works as an office secretary. Vital signs are within normal limits, and physical examination does not reveal any deformity or swelling of the wrist. Which of the following will best assist in diagnosing this patient’s underlying condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with pain and paresthesias in the distribution of the median nerve, and she has multiple risk factors for the development of carpal tunnel syndrome. Of the tests listed, the Phalen maneuver is most likely to reveal the underlying diagnosis.

Carpal tunnel syndrome is a multifactorial disease that primarily results from increased pressure in the intercarpal canal and associated compression of the median nerve. Median nerve compression manifests clinically with pain and paresthesias in the first three digits of the hand and half of the fourth digit. Pain and paresthesias are then often reproduced with movements that flex or extend the wrist.

Special maneuvers that aid in diagnosis include the Phalen test and Tinel test. In the Phalen test, the patient fully flexes the palms at the wrist with the elbow in full extension to provide extra pressure on the median nerve. The Phalen test is positive if these maneuvers elicit pain or paresthesia. The Tinel test involves repetitive tapping over the carpal tunnel and evaluating for reproducible pain or paresthesia. Further diagnostic tests include nerve conduction studies and electromyography to rule out other polyneuropathies, plexopathies, and radiculopathies.

Treatment is primarily conservative, with physical therapy and wrist splinting as mainstays for mild or moderate disease. Additional therapies include oral or injection corticosteroids. Surgical release of the median nerve is reserved for cases that are refractory to conservative measures or those with advanced disease, characterized by evidence of axonal loss on nerve conduction studies.  

Option Analysis

✅ Phalen maneuver  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Finkelstein test:
Incorrect: The Finkelstein test is a physical examination maneuver used to determine if there is tenosynovitis in the abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis tendons of the wrist. In contrast, this patient has paresthesias in the median nerve distribution, more consistent with carpal tunnel syndrome.  
❌ Hook test:
Incorrect: Distal biceps tendon rupture can be diagnosed using the hook test. In contrast, this patient has paresthesias in the median nerve distribution, more consistent with carpal tunnel syndrome.  
❌ CT of the wrist  :
Incorrect: CT of the wrist is generally non-contributory in evaluating carpal tunnel syndrome unless there is a concern for a compressive mass lesion.  
❌ MRI of the wrist  :
Incorrect: Like CT, MRI of the wrist is generally non-contributory in evaluating carpal tunnel syndrome unless there is a concern for a compressive mass lesion.

questions.text: A 40-year-old comes to the office for the evaluation of an abdominal lump. The patient also reports intermittent pain in the upper abdomen that gets worse when they lift heavy weights at the gym. The rest of the review of systems is unremarkable. Past medical history is noncontributory. BMI is 35 kg/m2. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a 2 cm midline bulge between the umbilicus and xiphoid process. The bulge is erythematous, tender to palpation, and increases in size when the patient is asked to cough. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient’s midline abdominal bulge in the epigastric region that increases in size with increased intraabdominal pressure is most likely an epigastric hernia, which results when there is a defect in the linea alba of the abdominal wall.

A hernia is when an organ protrudes through the body wall that normally contains it. Ventral abdominal hernias occur in the anterior abdominal wall and can be divided into:

  •  Epigastric hernia (as described above) 
  •  Umbilical (periumbilical) hernia: Occurs near the umbilicus, often associated with pregnancy 
  •  Spigelian hernia: Located in the "Spigelian hernia belt," a transverse 6-centimeter-wide zone around the level of the arcuate line 
  • Incisional hernia: Usually develops on a prior surgical incision site where the fascia never fully healed
Risk factors for ventral hernias include obesity, pregnancy, heavy lifting, genetic defects, aging, and intractable vomiting.



Reducible hernias can be pushed back into the abdomen by applying manual pressure, whereas irreducible (i.e. incarcerated) hernias are trapped within the hernia sac and cannot be reduced. An incarcerated hernia can progress to become a strangulated hernia due to the progressive edema secondary to impaired blood and lymphatic flow, leading to ischemic necrosis of the herniated contents.



Option Analysis

✅ Defect in the linea alba:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Defect in the Spigelian aponeurosis:
Incorrect: A defect in the Spigelian aponeurosis can result in Spigelian hernia, which is located in the "Spigelian hernia belt," a transverse 6-centimeter-wide zone around the level of the arcuate line, which is the caudal-most extent of the posterior rectus sheath. It is not located in the epigastric region.
❌ Patent processus vaginalis:
Incorrect: Patent processus vaginalis can result in indirect inguinal hernia, in which the abdominal contents go through the inguinal ring and protrudes lateral to the epigastric vessels into the inguinal canal and sometimes the scrotum. This patient has an epigastric hernia.
❌ Weakness of the obturator membrane:
Incorrect: Weakness of the obturator membrane can cause an obturator hernia, in which the abdominal contents protrude through the obturator foramen, which is located on the anterolateral aspect of the pelvic wall. This patient has an epigastric hernia.
❌ Weakness of the transversalis fascia:
Incorrect: Weakness of the transversalis fascia can result in direct inguinal hernia, in which the abdominal contents protrude medially to the inferior epigastric vessels within the Hesselbach triangle and appear in the groin (unlike the epigastric bulge in this patient).

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with worsening stiffness in the right hand. Over the past several months, the patient has had difficulty extending the right ring finger. He states, “I feel like my finger is under constant tension. I think my father had a similar condition.” Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination of the right hand is notable for the findings demonstrated below. Further evaluation of the patient’s medical history will likely reveal which of the following?  


 Image reproduced from ">Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient presents with evidence of a Dupuytren contracture on physical examination. The condition is associated with a history of diabetes mellitus.

A Dupuytren contracture is characterized by slow, progressive fibroproliferation of the palmar fascia. The underlying etiology of this condition is unclear. However, this disease has several risk factors, including diabetes mellitus, chronic alcohol use, repetitive hand use, vibratory trauma, and smoking. In addition, there is a component of genetic predisposition, with a majority of patients being men of northern European ancestry.  

Clinically, Dupuytren contractures manifest with nodules on the palmar fascia and fingers. The nodules gradually lose flexibility and contract, resulting in the affected fingers being drawn into flexion. This condition is usually painless. However, Dupuytren contractures can become painful if the underlying tendon sheaths become inflamed.  

Option Analysis

✅ Diabetes mellitus  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hypertension:
Incorrect: Hypertension has not been independently associated with the development of Dupuytren contractures.  
❌ Hyperlipidemia  :
Incorrect: Hyperlipidemia has not been independently associated with the development of Dupuytren contractures.  
❌ Previous hand surgery  :
Incorrect: There is currently debate as to whether prior hand trauma or surgery lends towards the development of Dupuytren contracture. In contrast, diabetes mellitus is a well-documented risk factor for the development of this condition.  
❌ Epilepsy  :
Incorrect: Epilepsy is not a known risk factor for the development of Dupuytren contractures.

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician to evaluate bilateral wrist discomfort. The patient has had worsening pain and numbness over the first, second, and third digits and half of the fourth digit. She recently started working as a secretary and spends most of the day typing on a keyboard. She is currently undergoing treatment for breast cancer with anastrozole. The patient’s other medical problems include obesity, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and hyperthyroidism. She smokes half a pack of cigarettes daily and drinks one to two glasses of wine nightly. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination is notable for reproducible pain and paresthesias with a tapping of the volar aspect of the wrist. Which of the following factors most likely contributed to the development of this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with pain and paresthesias in the distribution of the median nerve and a positive Tinel test. These findings are consistent with carpal tunnel syndrome. Aromatase inhibitors have been shown to increase tendon thickness, which is thought to contribute to the development of median nerve entrapment.

Carpal tunnel syndrome is a multifactorial disease that primarily results from increased pressure in the intercarpal canal and associated compression of the median nerve. Median nerve compression manifests clinically with pain and paresthesias in the first three digits of the hand and half of the fourth digit. Pain and paresthesias are then often reproduced with movements that flex or extend the wrist.

Additional risk factors include obesity, female sex, diabetes, rheumatoid arthritis, and hypothyroidism. Workplace factors are also thought to contribute, with duties requiring repetitive hand and wrist use contributing to disease development.

Treatment is primarily conservative, with physical therapy and wrist splinting as mainstays of treatment, while surgery is reserved for advanced disease or cases refractory to conservative measures.

Option Analysis

✅ Aromatase-inhibitor use  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hypertension:
Incorrect: Hypertension is not a known risk factor for the development of carpal tunnel syndrome.  
❌ Smoking  :
Incorrect: Smoking is not a known risk factor for the development of carpal tunnel syndrome.  
❌ Hyperlipidemia:
Incorrect: Hyperlipidemia may contribute to obesity, a known risk factor for carpal tunnel syndrome. However, the patient’s use of aromatase-inhibitors is a more significant and direct risk factor for the development of carpal tunnel syndrome.  
❌ Hyperthyroidism:
Incorrect: Hypothyroidism, not hyperthyroidism, is a risk factor for the development of carpal tunnel syndrome.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man presents to the clinic with worsening knee pain for the past 5 months. He is currently training for a marathon, and the pain is brought on by running. His past medical history is unremarkable, and he does not take any medications. Physical examination is notable for tenderness to palpation over the lateral knee superior to the joint line at the lateral femoral epicondyle. There is no joint swelling of the knee and no gapping at the knee with valgus or varus testing. In addition, a test is performed that results in failure of the hip to adduct and lateral knee pain when the patient is lying with the affected side up and the distal leg is held with the hip abducted and extended and then dropped until motion is restricted. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with worsening lateral knee pain while engaged in running. Physical examination is notable for tenderness to palpation at the lateral femoral epicondyle and a positive Ober test. These findings are consistent with iliotibial band syndrome.

Iliotibial band syndrome is an overuse pain syndrome wherein pain occurs at the lateral knee as the iliotibial band crosses over the lateral femoral epicondyle. It is described as a sharp or burning pain that occurs only during activity. It is a common overuse syndrome often seen in runners and cyclists. Risk factors include weak hip adductors that place increased rotational strain on the iliotibial band, as well as an inherited leg-length discrepancy.

Diagnosis is primarily clinical, and advanced imaging is not needed. Key clinical findings include pain at the lateral femoral epicondyle and a positive Ober test or Noble test. For the Ober test, the knee is flexed to 90 °, the hip is abducted and extended, and the leg is released. Failure of the knee to adduct is a positive test and pain may be noted at the lateral knee. For the Noble test, the patient is supine, and the knee is bent back and forth several times from 0° to 90° while applying firm pressure on the lateral femoral epicondyle while the patient actively extends the hip and knee. The presence of palpable snapping, crepitus, or localized pain signifies a positive test.

Treatment of iliotibial band syndrome involves providing symptomatic relief and prescribing activity restriction, and physical therapy to correct mobility deficits.  

Option Analysis

✅ Iliotibial band syndrome:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Lateral meniscus tear:
Incorrect: Pain from lateral meniscal tears occurs at the joint line which is inferior to the location of the pain associated with iliotibial band syndrome. Lateral meniscus tears are typically associated with joint pain and swelling after an injury which this patient has not had..  
❌ Lateral collateral ligament tear:
Incorrect: While iliotibial band syndrome and lateral collateral ligament tears can occur concomitantly, it is unlikely given this patient has no knee gapping with stress testing on physical examination. Lateral collateral ligament tears typically occur after a high-energy blow to the knee or with extreme varus bending, neither of which have occurred in this patient.  
❌ Biceps femoris tendinopathy:
Incorrect: In this condition, tenderness is present at the tendon insertion at the lateral aspect of the fibular head rather than at the lateral femoral epicondyle. Pain is typically at the posterior aspect of the knee and outside of the knee joint.  
❌ Fibular head subluxation:
Incorrect: In this condition, tenderness to palpation is found at the fibular head, not at the lateral femoral epicondyle as seen in this patient. Also a prominence may be visible at the area of the fibular head.

questions.text:
A 39-year-old man presents to the clinic with worsening swelling and pain in his left knee. The pain has been ongoing for weeks and worsens with knee flexion. The patient works as a plumber and spends most of the day on his knees working in crawl spaces. He has a history of hypertension and diabetes and takes amlodipine and metformin daily. The patient smokes half a pack of cigarettes per day and drinks three beers on the weekends. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 93/min, respirations are 12/min, blood pressure is 146/75 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 95% on room air. The patient can fully flex and extend the knee and bear weight without significant pain. Physical examination is notable for the findings seen below, and a radiograph of the left knee is also shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
 
Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
Image reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with anterior knee pain and evidence of significant prepatellar bursal swelling from fluid accumulation. These findings are consistent with prepatellar bursitis.

Knee bursitis is a common condition that arises secondary to inflammation of bursa sacs surrounding the knee joint. Within the knee there are multiple bursal or fluid-filled synovial sacs that help to lubricate and cushion the skin, tendons, and bones. The commonly inflamed or injured bursa includes the prepatellar, infrapatellar, suprapatellar, and pes anserine bursa. Prepatellar and infrapatellar bursitis commonly occur in patients with chronic trauma to the anterior knee, such as those involved in professions who spend most of their day on their knees (e.g. plumbers). Suprapatellar bursitis is less common and often arises due to regression failure of the transverse septum formed in embryonic life between the suprapatellar plica and knee joint. The pes anserine bursa is located medially and commonly presents as swelling and pain at the medial aspect of the knee.

Clinically, knee bursitis presents as pain and swelling of the affected bursa without significant restrictions in the passive or active range of motion. The bursae are located extra-articularly, meaning the joint space itself remains unaffected when bursitis ensues. As a result, mobility within the joint itself remains unchanged. Additional clinical features include a preference to hold the knee in extension, warmth, erythema, and tenderness to palpation. Diagnosis is primarily clinical, but definitive diagnosis may involve MRI.  

Option Analysis

✅ Prepatellar bursitis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Patellar fracture:
Incorrect: This radiograph does not demonstrate evidence of bony abnormalities and this patient’s symptoms have been going on for weeks.  
❌ Septic arthritis:
Incorrect: Septic arthritis is in the differential of unilateral knee swelling. However, it is unlikely in this case given that the patient is afebrile, is able to bear weight on the affected knee, and can fully flex and extend the knee.  
❌ Pes anserine bursitis:
Incorrect: Pes anserine bursitis typically presents with pain and swelling on the medial aspect of the knee, not anteriorly as seen in this patient.
❌ Patellar tendonitis:
Incorrect: Patellar tendonitis will often present with anterior knee pain. However, significant swelling is typically not seen.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old woman who has no significant past medical history presents to the emergency department for evaluation following a motor vehicle collision. According to emergency medical services, the patient was the unrestrained driver of a vehicle traveling approximately 45 miles per hour that hit into the back of a stationary truck. Upon arrival, the patient is boarded, collared, and states she has pain in the back of the neck. The patient states, “My neck is killing me. I slammed my chin on the steering wheel”. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 104/min, respirations are 21/min, blood pressure is 172/94 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. A cervical spine radiograph is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

choices.text: Avulsion fracture of C3 spinous process
Vertebral body compression fracture of C2

questions.solution:
This patient presents after a motor vehicle collision wherein she likely sustained a hyperextension injury to the neck. The radiograph demonstrates spondylolisthesis of the C2 vertebra, which can be an unstable cervical spine injury. However this type of fracture typically does not cause spinal cord injury.  

Traumatic spondylolisthesis and associated fractures of the C2 vertebra are also known as “hangman’s injuries” or “hangman’s fracture”—since this was a common finding in post-mortem autopsies of criminals executed by hanging. This injury pattern now most commonly occurs from car crashes and falls. It is caused by forcible hyperextension of the head, usually with the distraction of the neck, or without distraction of the neck but with axial loading.  

The fracture typically occurs in the axis's superior and inferior articular processes, with an associated displacement of the C2 vertebra anteriorly on C3. Spinal cord or brainstem injury can occur if the fracture is unstable. Radiographically, it can be identified by anterior displacement of the C2 vertebra relative to C3 If the fracture is stable then treatment is typically conservative with external fixation or bracing.  

Option Analysis

✅ Spondylolisthesis of C2  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Burst fracture of C1  :
Incorrect: A burst fracture of C1 is also known as a Jefferson fracture. It can be an unstable cervical spine injury, but typically is not and is treated with a collar. This injury more commonly occurs after a direct compression force is applied to the top of the head, and it may be difficult to identify on radiographs.  
❌ Odontoid fracture:
Incorrect: The odontoid process, or dens, is a superior projecting bony element from the second cervical vertebrae that may become fractured during hyperextension or hyperflexion injuries. An associated fracture of the dens is not apparent on this radiograph. It is best identified on CT imaging of the head and neck.  
❌ Avulsion fracture of C3 spinous process:
Incorrect: An avulsion fracture of a spinous process, also referred to as a “clay-shoveler fracture”, is a rare fracture which is considered a stable cervical spine injury. There is no evidence of a C3 spinous process fracture in this patient’s radiograph.  
❌ Vertebral body compression fracture of C2:
Incorrect: Vertebral body compression fractures most commonly arise in patients with  underlying osteoporosis. They appear as a wedge-shaped vertebral body on radiographic imaging.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the office for evaluation of difficulty wearing her shoes due to medial eminence of the right big toe. She is a dancer which requires her to work for twelve hours a day wearing specially fitted, tight closed shoes. The patient also reports pain worse with weight-bearing and when wearing her shoes. Past medical history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows lateral deviation of the right great toe and enlargement of a medially deviated first metatarsal head. Skin over the enlarged toe is hard, warm, and red. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s toe pain?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with lateral deviation of the great toe and enlargement of the medially deviated first metatarsal head, suggestive of hallux valgus (bunion).

Hallux valgus is a progressive foot deformity that occurs when the first metatarsal head deviates medially, producing a painful bump causing the hallux to compensate with lateral deviation. Patients usually present with a prominent bump at the medial side of the metatarsophalangeal joint (MTP) joint.

Common risk factors include gender (women), footwear (tight pointed shoes), congenital deformity, or chronic achilles tension. Symptoms can range in severity from mild to severe discomfort, aggravated by standing, walking, or wearing narrow or stiff shoes. Examination and radiographs reveal the diagnosis.    Pressure and friction from prolonged hallux valgus deformity can lead to the development of corn(s), which are hyperkeratotic localized overgrowths.    

Option Analysis

❌ Gout :
Incorrect: Patients with gout often report a relatively sudden onset of severe symptoms including pain, swelling, and redness. This patient’s deformity developed insidiously. 
❌ Hallux rigidus :
Incorrect: Patients with hallux rigidus will typically present with pain, stiffness, and swelling in the first MTP joint, aggravated by repetitive dorsiflexion at the MTP joint. Physical examination will reveal limited and often painful range of motion of the big toe, along with crepitus. Prominent osteophytes on the dorsal aspect of the joint are usually visible and palpable. Lateral deviation of the great toe with enlargement of the medially deviated first metatarsal head is seen in hallux valgus. 
✅ Hallux valgus :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Charcot arthropathy :
Incorrect: Charcot joint presents with deformity and sensory deficits of the foot due to trauma and impaired proprioception and sensation of pain. Patients often have underlying diabetes mellitus.  
❌ Turf toe :
Incorrect: Turf toe refers to an acute injury at the MTP joint when the great toe is forced superiorly injuring the plantar plate. A classic mechanism is an athlete jamming his or her foot against a hard surface. Prominent enlargement on the medial foot is suggestive of hallux valgus deformity.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the office for evaluation of right inguinal swelling that he first noticed today while showering. The patient reports mild discomfort. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Current medications include metformin, atorvastatin, and lisinopril. Family history is significant for prostate cancer in the patient’s father. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows enlarged, tender right inguinal and popliteal lymph nodes. Which of the following conditions, if found, would most likely explain this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Painless ulceration on the glans penis
Old laceration of the right lateral foot with purulence

questions.solution:
Lymphadenopathy is characterized by an abnormality in size, number, or consistency of any lymphatic nodes and usually occurs in response to infection, malignancy, or an auto-immune condition.

The lower extremity lymphatic system gets divided into both superficial and deep lymphatic vessels, which follow the path of the venous and arterial system. The superficial lymphatic vessels drain lymph from the skin and subcutaneous tissues, whereas the deep lymphatic system drains lymph from both the superficial vessels and deep muscles. The superficial system is further divided into both medial and lateral tracks.
 

Therefore, an infected lesion on the lateral foot would result in the enlargement of both popliteal and inguinal lymph nodes, in contrast to medial foot lesions (only inguinal lymphadenopathy). 

Lymph from the superficial and deep inguinal lymph nodes traverses the external and common iliac nodes before entering the lateral lumbar (aortic) lymph nodes and the lumbar lymphatic trunk.       

Option Analysis

❌ Firm nontender right testicular mass :
Incorrect: Lymph from the testes drains directly into the para-aortic lymph nodes, not the inguinal lymph nodes.  
❌ Asymmetric firm prostatic nodules :
Incorrect: Lymph from the prostate drains into the internal iliac lymph nodes, not the inguinal lymph nodes.  
❌ Painless ulceration on the glans penis :
Incorrect: The glans penis is drained by the deep lymphatic system into the deep (not superficial) inguinal lymph node.  
❌ Exudative pharyngitis  :
Incorrect: Infectious mononucleosis results in cervical (not inguinal) lymph node enlargement. 
✅ Old laceration of the right lateral foot with purulence :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old man is brought to the emergency department to be evaluated for head trauma following a dive into a shallow swimming pool. Upon extrication, the patient was found to have profuse bleeding from the scalp. Reflexes in the upper and lower extremities were intact, there was good sphincter tone and no Babinski sign. He was subsequently brought to the nearest emergency department in a cervical collar and sent to the CT scanner for further evaluation. A CT of the cervical spine is shown below, as is the lateral cervical radiograph. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of injury resulting in these imaging findings?



Images reproduced from Radiopedia

choices.text: Vertical compression to the neck from axial loading
Hyperflexion and internal rotation of the neck
Lateral force applied to the neck

questions.solution:
This patient presents with imaging findings of anterior and posterior arch fractures or a burst fracture of the C1 vertebra (atlas), also known as a Jefferson fracture. The most common mechanism of injury associated with this fracture pattern is a vertical compression force applied to the neck from axial loading.  

Jefferson fractures often result from motor vehicle accidents, shallow-water diving injuries, or falls from extreme heights. This fracture pattern involves a fracture of the anterior and posterior arches of C1, most commonly due to axial loading transmitted through the occipital condyles to the lateral masses. Jefferson fractures are not typically associated with spinal cord injuries unless a bone fragment injures the spinal cord. However they are often associated with other cervical spine injuries. They are considered stable and treated conservatively with cervical spine collar immobilization unless the transverse atlantal ligament is disrupted which is an unstable injury.  

Imaging of the vertebral arteries with CT angiography or MR angiography is an important part of the evaluation due to concerns for the rare complication of late-onset neurologic deficits from cerebellar infarction caused by blood flow disruptions to the vertebral arteries. When an injury occurs to the vertebral arteries, patients are at risk for developing stroke syndromes such as lateral medullary syndrome, Horner syndrome, ataxia, or the inability to sense pain or temperature.

Option Analysis

✅ Vertical compression to the neck from axial loading  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hyperextension of the neck:
Incorrect: A hangman fracture refers to a fracture of both pedicles, or pars interarticularis, of the C2 vertebra which can lead to traumatic spondylolisthesis of C2. The most common mechanism of injury associated with this traumatic injury is hyperextension of the neck. The lateral cervical radiograph does not show fractures of the C2 pedicles. In contrast, this patient has a fracture of the C1 vertebra on CT.  
❌ Hyperflexion of the neck  :
Incorrect: Hyperflexion of the neck is the most common mechanism of injury associated with a fracture of the spinous processes of the lower cervical or upper thoracic vertebrae. This injury is also known as a “clay-shoveler fracture”. The lateral cervical radiograph does not show fracture of the spinous processes.  
❌ Hyperflexion and internal rotation of the neck:
Incorrect: Hyperflexion and internal rotation of the neck is the most common mechanism associated with an atlanto-axial dislocation. There is no evidence of the on lateral cervical radiograph of atlanto-axial dislocation, and the patient has none of the neurologic symptoms that are typically seen with atlanto-axial dislocation.  
❌ Lateral force applied to the neck  :
Incorrect: A lateral force applied to the neck is more likely to injure the vertebral transverse processes. The CT does not demonstrate transverse process fractures.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a fall down the last step of a flight of stairs. The patient drank several beers earlier during the day and slipped as he was going down the staircase. He landed face first and hyperextended his neck. The patient has facial pain and pain in the posterior cervical spine. Past medical history is unremarkable. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 162/84 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. The patient is placed in a cervical spine collar. A CT of the cervical spine is obtained, and the coronal and sagittal views are shown below. Which of the following best describes this pattern of injury?  



Image reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents following a fall down the last step of a flight of stairs and associated neck hypertension. CT imaging demonstrates a fracture through the base of the odontoid process, which is consistent with a type II odontoid fracture.  

Odontoid fractures are the most common type of cervical spine injury seen in older patients and refer to fractures of the odontoid process (dens of C2 vertebra). They often occur in older patients as a result of low-energy falls. This injury pattern most commonly occurs secondary to forced hyperextension of the neck. Less commonly, it can arise via forced hyperflexion of the neck. These fractures can be recognized by bone discontinuation in the dens on an open mouth radiograph or CT scan.  

Odontoid fractures are classified into three distinct injury patterns. A type I odontoid fracture refers to an avulsion fracture of the tip of the odontoid process and represents a stable cervical spine injury. Type II and type III odontoid fractures represent unstable cervical spine injuries and refer to a fracture through the base of the odontoid process and a fracture through the C2 vertebral body, respectively. In particular, type II injuries are at risk of avascular necrosis and nonunion due to poor blood supply. Type III injuries may heal faster due to adequate blood supply to the cervical body but are at higher risk of causing neurologic injury secondary to mechanical instability.

Option Analysis

✅ Type II odontoid injury:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Type I odontoid fracture:
Incorrect: A type I odontoid fracture occurs when only the rostral tip of the odontoid process is avulsed. It is most often a stable cervical spine injury. This CT shows that there is a fracture through the base of the odontoid process not the tip..  
❌ Burst fracture of C1:
Incorrect: A burst fracture of C1 is also known as a Jefferson fracture. Jefferson fractures typically occur after a direct compression force from axial loading to the top of the head, not from a hyperextension injury of the neck as seen in this patient.  
❌ Type III odontoid injury  :
Incorrect: A type III odontoid fracture is a fracture through the body of the C2 vertebra. In contrast, this patient’s CT demonstrates a fracture through the base of the odontoid process.  
❌ Spondylolisthesis of C2:
Incorrect: Traumatic spondylolisthesis and associated fracture of the C2 vertebra are known as “hangman’s injuries” or “hangman’s fracture”. This type of injury typically results from forced hyperextension of the neck. Spondylolisthesis can be identified by anterior displacement of the C2 vertebra relative to the surrounding cervical vertebrae which is not seen in the sagittal view of this CT.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old man presents to the emergency department with left lower extremity pain and swelling. The patient was outside jogging when he suddenly felt a “pop” with associated pain behind the left knee. The left lower extremity has become progressively more swollen and painful over the past few hours. The patient recently traveled to the United States from London. Past medical history is notable for hypertension. Vital signs are within normal limits. Bilateral lower extremity pulses are normal and equal. Physical examination reveals a swollen and tender calf and ecchymosis at the popliteal region. Anterior and posterior drawer tests are negative. An ultrasound of the left calf is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
 

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient presents with acute onset of pain and swelling of the calf after jogging. Ultrasound reveals a hypoechoic fluid collection. These findings are consistent with a ruptured popliteal (Baker) cyst.

Popliteal cysts are common and reflect an enlargement of the gastrocnemius-semimembranosus bursa that extends into the adjacent knee joint space. Popliteal cysts are commonly associated with osteoarthritis, inflammatory arthritis, and a history of knee trauma (e.g. meniscus tears). They are typically asymptomatic unless rupture occurs.

Clinically, a popliteal cyst often presents as a swollen mass on the posterior aspect of the knee that can cause knee stiffness and difficulty with range of motion during exercise. Occasionally, popliteal cysts can rupture, causing acute pain and swelling of the calf that can mimic deep vein thrombosis. Management of a ruptured popliteal cyst should include ruling out a deep venous thrombosis. The fluid from a ruptured popliteal cyst will gradually be reabsorbed, therefore treatment is typically pain management, rest, and elevation.  

Option Analysis

✅ Ruptured popliteal cyst:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Deep vein thrombosis:
Incorrect: While this patient has recently been on a long-distance flight, his physical examination and ultrasound findings are consistent with a ruptured popliteal cyst. Ultrasound findings associated with a deep vein thrombosis include an incompressible vein and the absence of Doppler flow if the vessel is completely occluded.  
❌ Lymphedema:
Incorrect: Lymphedema often presents as chronic swelling and induration of the lower extremities due to cardiovascular disease, previous radiation, malignancy, infection, or trauma.  
❌ Femoral artery occlusion:
Incorrect: Femoral artery occlusion will often manifest with a pulseless lower extremity with associated acute pain and swelling. Risk factors include atrial fibrillation and thrombophilia.  
❌ Posterior cruciate ligament tear:
Incorrect: Posterior cruciate ligament tears are associated with positive posterior drawer testing. This finding is not present in this patient.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to the office to evaluate clumsiness and a pins-and-needles sensation in his right hand. The patient is worried that he won’t be able to participate in an upcoming road bicycle race due to his hand weakness. The patient suffered a fall while riding his bicycle four months ago. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination of the right hand demonstrates hypothenar eminence atrophy, decreased sensation over the 4th and 5th digits, diminished finger abduction, and weakness in adduction of the fingers and thumb adduction. Which of the following is the most likely site of nerve injury?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent with distal ulnar nerve injury, most likely due to a fracture of the hook of the hamate.   

The ulnar nerve originates from the medial cord of the brachial plexus (C8-T1) and courses with the brachial artery in the upper arm to enter the forearm after passing posterior to the medial epicondyle of the humerus.  



In a distal ulnar nerve injury (e.g. fracture of the hook of hamate or compression from bicycle handlebar), patients often endorse numbness and paresthesias of the medial 1½ digits of the hand, decreased abduction of the fingers (weakness in the intrinsic interosseous muscles), weakness in adduction of the fingers and thumbs, as well as hypothenar eminence atrophy. This injury often manifests as an “ulnar claw,” meaning that when the patient attempts to extend the fingers, the 4th and 5th digits remain extended at the MCP, while the DIP and PIP remain flexed.  

Common mechanisms of ulnar injury at the elbow include medial epicondyle fractures, trauma, or prolonged leaning or sleeping on an object. In addition to distal deficits, patients present with loss of function of the flexor digitorum profundus medially. When asked to make a fist, patients cannot flex the 4th and 5th digits resulting in an “OK gesture.”  In addition, the wrist will demonstrate radial deviation  with flexion (loss of flexor carpi ulnaris).  



Option Analysis

❌ Surgical neck of the humerus:
Incorrect: A fracture of the surgical neck of the humerus commonly results from a fall on an outstretched hand and is most likely to damage the axillary nerve. It typically presents with weakness of arm adduction at the shoulder and loss of sensation of the lateral upper arm.
❌ Midshaft of the humerus:
Incorrect: The radial nerve is most commonly injured with midshaft humerus fractures. Injury results in weakness of wrist, finger, and thumb extension and weakness with elbow supination. This patient most likely sustained an ulnar nerve injury at the hook of the hamate.
❌ Coracobrachialis:
Incorrect: The coracobrachialis muscle is innervated by the musculocutaneous nerve. Damage to this nerve results in weakness with forearm flexion and supination, as well as the sensory loss over the lateral forearm.
❌ Carpal tunnel:
Incorrect: The median nerve can be compressed in the carpal tunnel, resulting in pain and paraesthesias in the radial 3½ digits, weakness of the first and second lumbrical, thenar atrophy, and weakness of thumb abduction and opposition. The medial 1½ digits are spared in these patients.
✅ Hook of the hamate:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a head-on motor vehicle collision. He was the restrained driver and used his arm to brace the impact. He did not strike his head or lose consciousness. Past medical history is noncontributory, and the patient does not take any medications.  Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates an inability to extend the right wrist and sensory loss over the posterior forearm and dorsolateral hand. Which of the following best describes the underlying mechanism of injury responsible for this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Fracture of the medial epicondyle of the humerus

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent with radial nerve injury, most likely due to a midshaft fracture of the humerus. The radial nerve carries fibers from C5-T1 and serves as the terminal branch of the brachial plexus. It provides motor innervation to the forearm extensors at the elbow and most hand extensors at the wrist. Cutaneous sensory innervation includes the posterior forearm and most of the back of the hand, except for the back of the little finger and the adjacent half of the ring finger (innervated by the ulnar nerve).  


The deep branch of the radial nerve can be injured as it passes through the supinator muscle secondary to repetitive pronation/supination (use of screwdrivers). Patients typically present with weakness of finger and thumb extension (without wrist drop and preserved sensation, unlike this patient).  

Radial nerve injury by a midshaft humerus fracture results in weakness of wrist, finger, and thumb extension, as well as with elbow supination. Loss of sensation over the posterior arm/forearm and dorsal hand is also observed. Injury at this location preserves the triceps reflex.  

Finally, compression at the brachial plexus (e.g., due to crutches or sleeping with the arm over a chair i.e. “Saturday night palsy”) can induce radial nerve injury. Injury at this location results in paralysis of the triceps, leading to loss of elbow extension, in addition to the loss of wrist and finger extension.  




Option Analysis

✅ Midshaft humerus fracture:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Superficial laceration of the palm:
Incorrect: A superficial laceration of the palm can injure the recurrent branch of the median nerve, resulting in loss of thenar muscle group function (i.e., opposition, abduction, and flexion of thumb). 
❌ Fracture of the medial epicondyle of the humerus:
Incorrect: The ulnar nerve is at risk of injury as it courses posterior to the medial epicondyle before entering the forearm. Patients endorse numbness and paresthesias of the medial 1½ digits of the hand, decreased abduction of the fingers, weakness in adduction of the fingers and thumbs, as well as hypothenar eminence atrophy. Flexion, rather than extension, of the wrist is impaired with this injury pattern.
❌ Anterior dislocation of the humerus:
Incorrect: Anterior dislocations of the humerus can injure the axillary nerve, resulting in loss of arm abduction at the shoulder (> 15°) and loss of sensation over the deltoid and upper arm.
❌ Repetitive pronation/supination of forearm:
Incorrect: The deep branch of the radial nerve can be injured as it passes through the supinator muscle secondary to repetitive pronation/supination (e.g. use of screwdrivers). Patients typically present with weakness of finger and thumb extension with preserved sensation.

questions.text: An examiner touches the forehead, cheeks, and chin of a patient with a cotton wisp to test the sensation of light touch in these regions. Which of the following cranial nerves is tested by the examiner?
questions.solution:
Cranial nerves emerge directly from the brain, including the brainstem. There are twelve pairs of cranial nerves that relay information between the brain and parts of the body. The trigeminal nerve (CN V) and its three main branches, the ophthalmic (V1), maxillary (V2), and mandibular (V3) nerves, provide sensation to the skin of the face and also control the muscles of mastication. The cranial nerves and their functions are summarized below:  



Option Analysis

✅ Trigeminal nerve:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Abducens nerve  :
Incorrect: The abducens nerve innervates the lateral rectus muscle, which is responsible for outward gaze of the eyes.  
❌ Facial nerve  :
Incorrect: The facial nerve controls facial movement, taste from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, lacrimation, salivation (submandibular and sublingual glands are innervated by CN VII), eye closing (orbicularis oculi), and auditory volume modulation (stapedius).  
❌ Vagus nerve  :
Incorrect: The vagus nerve is responsible for taste from the supraglottic region, swallowing, soft palate elevation, midline uvula, talking, cough reflex, parasympathetics to thoracoabdominal viscera, and monitoring of the aortic arch chemoreceptors and baroreceptors.  
❌ Accessory nerve  :
Incorrect: The accessory nerve supplies the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles. The sternocleidomastoid muscle tilts and rotates the head. The trapezius muscle, which connects to the scapula, acts to shrug the shoulder.

questions.text: A scientist is studying the hypothalamus and discovers that damaging a specific portion of the organ leads to abnormal sleep patterns. Specifically, she finds that the sleep cycle is no longer coordinated with the light/dark cycle of the environment and instead occurs randomly throughout the day. Which structure in the hypothalamus was most likely damaged?
questions.solution:
The hypothalamus is a major center of homeostatic regulation and is divided into multiple nuclei with distinct functions. The suprachiasmatic nucleus integrates visual signals with internal clocks to control the circadian rhythm. The lateral nucleus promotes appetite, whereas the ventromedial nucleus inhibits appetite. The anterior and posterior nuclei work together to regulate thermogenesis. The supraoptic and paraventricular nuclei function as part of the endocrine system releasing vasopressin and oxytocin. The preoptic nucleus is involved in thermoregulation and sexual behavior.  



Option Analysis

❌ Lateral nucleus:
Incorrect: The lateral nucleus is responsible for promoting appetite. Damage to this hypothalamic region would result in decreased appetite and weight loss.
❌ Paraventricular nuclei:
Incorrect: The paraventricular nuclei are involved in releasing vasopressin and oxytocin. A lesion to this region would disrupt endocrine function, specifically regarding the regulation of serum osmolality.
❌ Posterior nucleus:
Incorrect: The posterior area nucleus regulates body temperature. A lesion to this hypothalamic region would result in poikilothermia.
✅ Suprachiasmatic nucleus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Ventromedial nucleus:
Incorrect: The ventromedial nucleus is responsible for inhibiting appetite. Damage to this hypothalamus region would result in increased appetite and weight gain.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) began his first cycle of chemotherapy two days ago. Today, he endorses severe nausea and vomiting. Which of the following structures is involved in the pathway responsible for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient's nausea and vomiting are a result of stimulation of the chemoreceptor trigger zone (CTZ) located within the area postrema. This structure is found on the floor of the fourth ventricle at the caudal end of the rhomboid fossa, near the entrance of the central canal. The CTZ does not have a well-developed blood-brain barrier but rather fenestrated capillaries, allowing chemical substances to cross from the bloodstream. Thus the CTZ  can sense emetogenic substances, including chemotherapeutics, alcohol, toxins, and hormones that directly stimulate the vomiting reflex.  

Option Analysis

✅ Area postrema  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Medial geniculate nucleus  :
Incorrect: The medial geniculate nucleus is a thalamic structure that projects to the auditory cortex of the temporal lobe and is involved in processing auditory information.  
❌ Lateral geniculate nucleus  :
Incorrect: The lateral geniculate nucleus is a thalamic structure that projects to the calcarine sulcus and is involved in processing visual information.  
❌ Posterior hypothalamus  :
Incorrect: The posterior hypothalamus is responsible for the body's ability to warm itself via sympathetic output.  
❌ Ventral pons  :
Incorrect: The ventral pons contains the corticospinal tract (limb/torso movements), corticobulbar tract (face/head/neck movements), and abducens nucleus (lateral eye movements).

questions.text: A 66-year-old man is evaluated for dysphagia and recurrent aspiration pneumonia. The patient has hypertension and often forgets to take his blood pressure medications. Temperature is 37.0ºC (98.6ºF), blood pressure is 162/95 mmHg, and pulse is 87/min. Physical examination reveals an absent right-sided gag reflex. Loss of function of the nerve responsible for transmitting the afferent signal of this reflex is associated with which of the following additional neurological deficits?

choices.text: Loss of sensation in the posterior one-third of the tongue.
Loss of taste sensation in the anterior two-thirds of the tongue

questions.solution:
This patient with a history of poorly controlled hypertension and recurrent aspiration pneumonia presents with an absent right-sided gag reflex. Afferent signals of the gag reflex are sent via the glossopharyngeal nerve, which is also responsible for sensation in the posterior one-third of the tongue.  

A reflex arc typically consists of sensory receptors, the afferent sensory nerve that sends an impulse to the central nervous system, and an efferent motor nerve that transmits a motor response. The gag reflex is mediated by the glossopharyngeal nerve and the vagus nerve. The gag reflex is triggered via contact with the posterior pharynx, tonsillar area, or tongue base. Afferent nerve impulses (sensory limb) are sent through the glossopharyngeal nerve (IX), which also aids in swallowing by supplying the stylopharyngeus muscle and carries taste from the posterior third of the tongue. Efferent nerve impulses (motor limb) are then sent through the pharyngeal branches of the vagus nerve (X), which also innervates muscles of the pharynx and larynx and helps regulate blood pressure.  



The gag reflex is assessed when there is reason to suspect reduced palatal strength or sensation (e.g. clinical symptoms of stroke). It is evaluated by observing the patient’s response when the posterior pharynx is touched with a cotton swab. The reflex elicited on one side can be compared with that of the contralateral side to assess for asymmetry.  

A normal gag reflex involves brisk, symmetrical elevation of the soft palate and contraction of pharyngeal muscles. If both cranial nerves IX and X are damaged, stimulation of the affected side would fail to elicit a reflex. Loss of the gag reflex makes patients susceptible to aspiration and pneumonia.  

Option Analysis

✅ Loss of sensation in the posterior one-third of the tongue.:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Loss of taste sensation in the anterior two-thirds of the tongue:
Incorrect: Taste sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue is transmitted via the facial nerve, while somatosensation is transmitted via the trigeminal nerve. In contrast, the glossopharyngeal nerve, which carries the afferent signals of the gag reflex and is likely damaged here, is responsible for taste and somatosensation of the posterior one-third of the tongue.     
❌ Vocal cord paralysis:
Incorrect: The vagus nerve is responsible for the motor supply of the vocal cords. It carries the efferent signal of the gag reflex. The glossopharyngeal nerve carries the afferent signal of the gag reflex, in addition to sensation in the posterior one-third of the tongue.
❌ Tongue paralysis:
Incorrect: Most of the tongue muscles are supplied by the hypoglossal nerve. The exception is the palatoglossal muscle provided by the vagus nerve. However, this patient has an absent gag reflex, and the afferent signals of the gag reflex are transmitted via the glossopharyngeal nerve, which is also responsible for sensation in the posterior one-third of the tongue.
❌ Loss of the cough reflex:
Incorrect: The vagus nerve mediates both the afferent and efferent signals of the cough reflex. In contrast, this patient has an absent gag reflex. The afferent signals of the gag reflex are transmitted via the glossopharyngeal nerve, which is also responsible for sensation in the posterior one-third of the tongue.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of dysarthria and dysphagia. The patient’s symptoms started three months ago. Past medical history includes type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension, both poorly controlled. Current medications include metformin, glyburide, losartan, and atorvastatin. He has a 40-pack-year smoking history. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 162/89 mmHg, and pulse is 80/min. Examination of the head and neck reveals atrophy and fasciculations of the tongue. Rightward deviation of the tongue is noted when the patient is asked to protrude the tongue. He has no sensory or motor abnormalities in other parts of the face or the body. Further evaluation of this patient’s clinical history will most likely reveal the following?

choices.text: History of stroke involving the right medullary branch of the vertebral artery
Lymph node biopsy from the posterior cervical lymph nodes
Thyroidectomy with superior and inferior thyroid arteries dissection
Mitral stenosis associated with left atrial dilation

questions.solution:
The hypoglossal nerve emerges from the anterior surface of the medulla oblongata and leaves the skull through the hypoglossal canal. It descends through the neck close to the internal carotid artery, internal jugular vein, and vagus nerve. The hypoglossal nerve supplies the intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue, except the palatoglossal muscle, which is supplied by the vagus nerve.    

Hypoglossal nerve injury can occur anywhere along the nerve’s course. Etiologies include tumor, cerebrovascular injury, demyelinating diseases, injury following cervical spine surgery, and traumatic injury. In addition, the hypoglossal nerve can be injured during operations involving the upper part of the anterior neck. It is especially susceptible to injury during carotid endarterectomy.   

Features of hypoglossal nerve injury include tongue atrophy and fasciculations and ipsilateral paralysis of one-half of the tongue. Moreover, when the patient is asked to stick out their tongue, the tongue will deviate towards the side of nerve injury.  



Option Analysis

✅ Right carotid artery endarterectomy :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ History of stroke involving the right medullary branch of the vertebral artery :
Incorrect: A stroke involving the medullary branch of the vertebral artery will result in medial medullary syndrome. The condition is associated with hypoglossal nerve palsy, contralateral weakness of the body, and contralateral sensory loss. In contrast, this patient has isolated hypoglossal nerve palsy, which would more likely arise as a complication of carotid surgery.
❌ Lymph node biopsy from the posterior cervical lymph nodes:
Incorrect: The spinal accessory nerve can be injured during a lymph node biopsy in the posterior cervical region. Spinal accessory nerve injury can present with shoulder pain, limited abduction of the shoulder beyond 90 degrees, and shoulder drop. However, it would not present with dysarthria, dysphagia, or tongue deviation.
❌ Thyroidectomy with superior and inferior thyroid arteries dissection :
Incorrect: The superior laryngeal nerve can be injured during dissection of the superior thyroid artery, and the recurrent laryngeal nerve can be damaged during dissection of the inferior thyroid artery. However, this patient’s symptoms are more suggestive of hypoglossal nerve injury.
❌ Mitral stenosis associated with left atrial dilation :
Incorrect: Left atrial dilation can cause compression of the left recurrent laryngeal nerve and associated hoarseness of the voice. In contrast, this patient’s symptoms suggest hypoglossal nerve injury.

questions.text: The central nervous system is composed of the cerebrum, cerebellum, brainstem, and spinal cord. Furthermore, the brainstem can be divided into the medulla oblongata, pons, and midbrain. Which of the following statements regarding the brainstem is true?

choices.text: The substantia nigra is located in the tectum of the midbrain.
The superior colliculus relays voluntary and involuntary eye movements.
The inferior colliculus project to the lateral geniculate bodies.
The inferior olivary nucleus is located in the tegmentum of the midbrain.
The red nucleus forms part of the subcortical visual system.

questions.solution:
The superior and inferior colliculus are located in the tectum of the midbrain, which is posterior to the cerebral aqueduct and forms the roof of the midbrain.    

The superior colliculus relays voluntary and involuntary eye movements (e.g. saccades), facilitates optic reflexes, receives input from the retina and pretectal area, and projects to the lateral geniculate bodies.   

In contrast, the inferior colliculus is a part of the auditory pathway. It receives input from the lateral lemniscus and projects to the medial geniculate bodies.



Option Analysis

❌ The substantia nigra is located in the tectum of the midbrain.:
Incorrect: The substantia nigra is located in the tegmentum of the midbrain. 
✅ The superior colliculus relays voluntary and involuntary eye movements.:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ The inferior colliculus project to the lateral geniculate bodies.:
Incorrect: The inferior colliculus projects to the medial geniculate bodies. 
❌ The inferior olivary nucleus is located in the tegmentum of the midbrain.:
Incorrect: The inferior olivary nucleus is located in the medulla oblongata, instead of the midbrain. 
❌ The red nucleus forms part of the subcortical visual system.:
Incorrect: The red nucleus is part of the extrapyramidal motor system. In contrast, it is not part of the subcortical visual system.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman comes to the emergency room for evaluation of palpitations. An electrocardiogram is performed and demonstrates sinus tachycardia. A carotid sinus massage is completed, and the patient’s heart rate decreases from 180/min to 100/min. Which of the following is true regarding the response seen in this patient?

choices.text: Afferent signals from the carotid body are transmitted via the glossopharyngeal nerve, while efferent impulses (the response) are transmitted via the vagus nerve.
Afferent signals from the carotid body and efferent signals to the aortic arch baroreceptors are transmitted via the vagus nerve.
Afferent signals from the carotid body are transmitted via the vagus nerve, while the efferent impulses (the response) are transmitted via the glossopharyngeal nerve.
Afferent signals from the carotid body and efferent signals (the response) are transmitted via the glossopharyngeal nerve.
Afferent signals from the carotid body are transmitted via the glossopharyngeal nerve, while the efferent impulses (the response) are transmitted via the accessory nerve.

questions.solution:
Baroreceptors are sensory receptors that detect changes in blood pressure and can modulate autonomic control of the heart and blood vessels through sympathetic and parasympathetic output. Baroreceptors are located within the carotid sinus and aortic arch. The glossopharyngeal nerve carries afferent impulses from the carotid sinus, whereas the vagus nerve carries afferent signals from the aortic arch. Signals from these receptors are relayed to the nucleus tractus solitarius (NTS) in the medulla. Autonomic output from the NTS is distributed via parasympathetic fibers of the vagus nerve or the sympathetic nervous system, depending on whether the body is trying to increase or decrease blood pressure.  



Baroreceptors in the carotid sinus and aortic arch are activated and send afferent impulses to the NTS. Efferent sympathetic fibers then relay signals from the NTS to the rest of the body, causing alterations in vasoconstriction, heart rate, and cardiac contractility. For instance, in cases of hypotension, there is diminished arterial stretch, which is noted by the baroreceptors, prompting a sympathetic response.  

In contrast, hypertension causes increased stretching of the arterial walls and baroreceptors. Signals are then forwarded to the NTS. Efferent parasympathetic output is relayed by the vagus nerve to the heart, resulting in bradycardia.  

Carotid sinus massage is a maneuver that can diagnose and treat supraventricular tachycardias such as atrioventricular reentrant tachycardia (AVRT) and AV nodal reentrant tachycardia (AVNRT). Pressure on the carotid sinus stretches the carotid sinus and baroreceptor activation. These changes increase parasympathetic output via the vagus nerve, slowing sinus node impulse formation and lengthening the AV node refractory period. These changes can potentially terminate an abnormal rhythm.  



Option Analysis

✅ Afferent signals from the carotid body are transmitted via the glossopharyngeal nerve, while efferent impulses (the response) are transmitted via the vagus nerve.:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Afferent signals from the carotid body and efferent signals to the aortic arch baroreceptors are transmitted via the vagus nerve.:
Incorrect: This patient demonstrated the baroreceptor reflex, in which the glossopharyngeal nerve transmits afferent information from the carotid body to the nucleus tractus solitarius. The vagus nerve then transmits efferent signals from the nucleus tractus solitarius to the aortic arch baroreceptors.  
❌ Afferent signals from the carotid body are transmitted via the vagus nerve, while the efferent impulses (the response) are transmitted via the glossopharyngeal nerve.:
Incorrect: This patient demonstrated the baroreceptor reflex, in which afferent signals from the carotid body are transmitted via the glossopharyngeal nerve, and subsequent efferent signals (the response) to the aortic arch baroreceptors are transmitted via the vagus nerve.  
❌ Afferent signals from the carotid body and efferent signals (the response) are transmitted via the glossopharyngeal nerve. :
Incorrect: In the baroreceptor reflex, efferent signals from the nucleus tractus solitarius are transmitted to the heart via the vagus nerve, not the glossopharyngeal nerve.  
❌ Afferent signals from the carotid body are transmitted via the glossopharyngeal nerve, while the efferent impulses (the response) are transmitted via the accessory nerve.    :
Incorrect: The accessory nerve (cranial nerve XI) is a pure motor nerve with no parasympathetic input. In contrast, the vagus nerve mediates the efferent response in the baroreceptor reflex.

questions.text: A researcher is currently studying the anatomy of the cranial nerve nuclei and pathways. He identifies the dorsal motor nucleus, which sends autonomic fibers to the upper gastrointestinal tract, heart, and lungs. Which of the following reflects the cranial nerve associated with the dorsal motor nucleus?
questions.solution:
The cranial nerve nuclei refer to collections of neurons in the brain stem associated with one or more of the cranial nerves. All nuclei are located in the tegmentum portion of the brainstem between the dorsal and ventral portions. The cranial nerve nuclei in each portion of the brainstem are outlined below:  

  •  Midbrain: CN III, IV 
  •  Pons: CN V, VI, VII, VIII 
  •  Medulla: CN IX, X, XII  
  •  Spinal cord: CN XI  
In addition, three vagal nuclei are associated with one or more cranial nerves that carry parasympathetic information, including the nucleus tractus solitarius (CN VII, CN IX, CNX), nucleus ambiguus (CN IX, X, XI), and the dorsal motor nucleus (CN X). The nucleus tractus solitarius mediates visceral sensory information, while the nucleus ambiguous mediates motor innervation of the throat and upper airway. Lastly, the dorsal motor nucleus sends autonomic fibers to the upper gastrointestinal tract, heart, and lungs.   

Option Analysis

✅ Cranial nerve X  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Cranial nerve VII:
Incorrect: Cranial nerve VII, or the facial nerve, provides innervation to the muscles of facial expression. The nucleus tractus solitarius is the nucleus associated with this cranial nerve.  
❌ Cranial nerve IX  :
Incorrect: Cranial nerve IX, or the glossopharyngeal nerve, is associated with both the nucleus tractus solitarius as well as the nucleus ambiguus. Cranial nerve IX is responsible for taste and sensation from the tongue, swallowing, and salivation. It does not, however, send autonomic signals to the heart, lungs, and gastrointestinal tract.  
❌ Cranial nerve XI  :
Incorrect: Cranial nerve XI is associated with the nucleus tractus solitarius but not the dorsal motor nucleus.  
❌ Cranial nerve III  :
Incorrect: Cranial nerve III, or the oculomotor nerve, originates from nuclei in the midbrain.

questions.text:
A pathologist views cross-sectional slides of the brainstem and identifies the following structure (denoted by an asterisk):  


Which of the following best characterizes the function of the fibers passing through this structure?

choices.text: Transmission of pain signals to the brain

questions.solution:
The asterisk points to the medullary pyramids and, in particular, the pyramidal decussations. Neurons of the lateral corticospinal tract decussate within the medullary pyramids.

The corticospinal tract is a descending pathway that regulates voluntary movements of the trunk and extremities. It can be subdivided into the anterior corticospinal tract, which contains around 5-15% of the fibers and controls proximal musculature, and lateral corticospinal tract, which contains around 75-90% of the fibers and controls musculature of the extremities.

First-order neurons originate from the motor cortex and descend through the internal capsule in both cases. Neurons within the lateral corticospinal tract decussate in the medullary pyramids and descend contralaterally until they reach the ventral horn, where they synapse with lower motor neurons. The lower motor neurons then leave the spinal cord via the ventral root and travel to the musculature.

Neurons of the anterior corticospinal tract, on the other hand, descend ipsilaterally until they reach the desired spinal segment. Afterward, the upper motor neurons decussate and synapse with lower motor neurons in the anterior horn. The lower motor neurons then leave the spinal cord via the ventral root and travel to the musculature.  



Option Analysis

❌ Regulation of muscles of mastication  :
Incorrect: The corticobulbar tract provides upper motor neuron innervation to many of the cranial nerves. This tract has several functions, including helping control muscles of the face, muscles of mastication, and muscles of the pharynx and larynx. Neurons in the corticobulbar tract decussate above the levels of the relevant cranial nuclei (and not at the medullary pyramids).  
❌ Transmission of pain signals to the brain  :
Incorrect: The spinothalamic tract relays pain, temperature, crude touch, and pressure sensations to the brain. However, fibers of the spinothalamic tract decussate in the anterior white commissure, as opposed to the medullary pyramids.  
✅ Initiation of voluntary arm movements  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Conduction of temperature sensation  :
Incorrect: The spinothalamic tract relays pain, temperature, crude touch, and pressure sensations to the brain. However, fibers of the spinothalamic tract decussate in the anterior white commissure, as opposed to the medullary pyramids.  
❌ Transmission of unconscious proprioceptive sensation  :
Incorrect: The spinocerebellar tract transmits unconscious proprioceptive sensation to the brain. After entering the spinal cord, the neurons either decussate immediately and become part of the ventral spinocerebellar tract (which later decussates again in the superior cerebellar peduncle) or ascend ipsilaterally as the dorsal spinocerebellar tract. Neither the ventral nor the dorsal spinocerebellar tracts decussate within the medullary pyramids.

questions.text:
A pathologist views cross-sectional slides of the spinal cord and identifies the following structure (denoted by an asterisk):  


Image reproduced from ">Wikimedia Commons  
Which of the following best characterizes the function of this structure?

choices.text: Transmission of pain signals to the brain

questions.solution:
The asterisk points to the dorsal column medial lemniscus tract, one of the three main ascending tracts in the spinal cord. The other two tracts are the spinothalamic tract and spinocerebellar tract. All three tracts enter the spinal cord via the dorsal root.

The dorsal column medial lemniscus (DCML) tract transmits delicate sensations including vibration, proprioception, two-point discrimination, and touch to the brain. Neurons in this tract ascend via the ipsilateral dorsal columns and decussate (crossover) within the nucleus gracilis and cuneatus of the medulla.

The spinothalamic tract transmits sensations including crude touch, pain, pressure, and temperature to the brain. Neurons ascend ipsilaterally for 1-2 spinal segments, decussate in the anterior white commissure, and ascend via one of two tracts in the anterior or lateral spinal cord.

Finally, there is the spinocerebellar tract, which transmits unconscious proprioceptive sensation to the brain. After entering the spinal cord, the neurons either decussate immediately and become part of the ventral spinocerebellar tract (which later decussates again in the superior cerebellar peduncle) or ascend ipsilaterally as the dorsal spinocerebellar tract.  



Option Analysis

❌ Inhibition of extensor motor neurons  :
Incorrect: The rubrospinal tract facilitates flexor and inhibits extensor motor neurons. However, the rubrospinal tract is located in the lateral white column instead of the dorsal white column.  
❌ Transmission of pain signals to the brain:
Incorrect: The spinothalamic tract relays pain, temperature, crude touch, and pressure sensations to the brain. The spinothalamic tract is located within the anterior and lateral portions of the spinal cord.  
❌ Initiation of voluntary hand movements  :
Incorrect: The corticospinal tract facilitates voluntary motor control of the trunk and extremities. The fibers of the corticospinal pathway can be found in the anterior and lateral portions of the spinal cord. In contrast, the asterisk is located within the dorsal white column, which houses the dorsal column medial lemniscus tract.  
❌ Conduction of temperature sensation  :
Incorrect: The spinothalamic tract relays pain, temperature, crude touch, and pressure sensations to the brain. The spinothalamic tract is located in the anterior and lateral portions of the spinal cord.  
✅ Transmission of vibratory sensation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to the physician to evaluate dysphagia and hoarseness that have been ongoing for the past three days. He has dysphagia with both solids and liquids. He has a history of poorly controlled hypertension. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 160/85 mmHg, and pulse is 92/min. Physical examination reveals decreased sensation over the posterior aspect of the tongue. The uvula deviates towards the right side. The appearance of the uvula suggests loss of function of which of the following nerves?
questions.solution:
The vagus nerve carries parasympathetic motor fibers to the somatic organs. It also provides motor supply to the muscles of the larynx, pharynx and soft palate.   

The main motor nucleus of the vagus nerve is situated within the reticular formation of the medulla oblongata. It receives inputs from the corticonuclear fibers and sends motor impulses via the direct pharyngeal branches of the vagus nerve to the constrictor muscles of the pharynx and soft palate (except for the tensor palatini muscles) and intrinsic muscles of the larynx.    

The uvula is a centrally located conic projection from the soft palate. If the pharyngeal branch of the vagus nerve is injured, the uvula will deviate away from the side of the lesion and towards the contralateral (unaffected) side. This phenomenon occurs due to a combination of intact palatal muscle pull on the contralateral side and palatal droop on the ipsilateral side.  

Additional symptoms seen in high vagal injuries include dysphagia from palatal weakness and paralysis of the constrictor muscles, in addition to hoarseness from impaired sensation from the superior laryngeal nerve (another branch of the vagus nerve).  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Right vagus nerve:
Incorrect: The uvula deviates towards the contralateral side from the causative lesion. As a result, rightwards deviation of the uvula is suggestive of a left vagus nerve injury.
✅ Left vagus nerve:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Left glossopharyngeal nerve :
Incorrect: Uvular deviation is due to vagal nerve injury and subsequent loss of palatal muscle function. Glossopharyngeal nerve injury does not cause uvular deviation.   
❌ Right glossopharyngeal nerve :
Incorrect: Uvular deviation is due to vagal nerve injury and subsequent loss of palatal muscle function. Glossopharyngeal nerve injury does not cause uvular deviation. 
❌ Left hypoglossal nerve :
Incorrect: The hypoglossal nerve is responsible for the movement of the tongue. Loss of the left hypoglossal nerve function will result in ipsilateral tongue deviation. In contrast, uvular deviation is due to vagus nerve injury.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man develops difficulty chewing after undergoing maxillofacial surgery. Physical examination reveals deviation of the jaw to the right side when the patient attempts to open his mouth. The nerve affected in this patient exits the skull via which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
This patient’s symptoms are consistent with injury of mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve (CN V3), which exits the skull via the foramen ovale in the middle cranial fossa. The nerves and vessels that enter and exit the skull via the different structures are summarized below:

Option Analysis

❌ Superior orbital fissure:
Incorrect: The superior orbital fissure carries cranial nerves III (oculomotor), IV (trochlear), VI (abducens), and V1 (ophthalmic division of CN V). In contrast, CN V3 provides innervation to the muscles of mastication. Injury to CN V3 would cause the jaw deviation experienced by this patient. 
❌ Foramen rotundum:
 \Incorrect: The foramen rotundum carries V2 (maxillary division of CN V). In contrast, CN V3 provides innervation to the muscles of mastication. Injury to CN V3 would cause the jaw deviation experienced by this patient. 
✅ Foramen ovale:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌  Foramen spinosum:
Incorrect: The foramen spinosum carries the middle meningeal artery. 
❌ Jugular foramen:
