Incorrect: The jugular foramen carries cranial nerves IX (glossopharyngeal), X (vagus), and XI (accessory). These nerves are not involved in controlling jaw movements or the muscles of mastication.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old woman presents to her outpatient provider for evaluation of chronic migraines. As part of the workup, a head CT with contrast is performed. Sagittal and axial images from the scan are shown below:


Image reproduced from Radiopedia.   

The walls of the structure indicated by the arrow are composed of the following?
questions.solution:
The dura mater is the tough, thick, outermost meningeal layer. It can be subdivided into the periosteal layer, which lies closer to the bone, and the meningeal layer, which lies closer to the brain tissue. The dural layers are usually fused but separate at certain regions to form the dural reflections and dural venous sinuses.  

The dural reflections are two face-to-face meningeal layers that descend into the cranial cavity to form septa that compartmentalize the brain. The primary dural reflections are the falx cerebri, which separates the two brain hemispheres, and tentorium cerebelli, which separates the cerebellum from the occipital lobe. Smaller dural reflections include the falx cerebelli, which separates the two cerebellar lobes, and diaphragma sellae, which forms a roof over the sella turcica.  

The dural venous sinuses are channels used to drain venous blood from the cerebral veins and drain cerebrospinal fluid from the subarachnoid space. The contents of the dural venous sinuses ultimately drain into the internal jugular vein. The major dural venous sinuses include the superior sagittal, inferior sagittal, straight (indicated by red arrow), transverse, and sigmoid sinuses. Smaller ones have the cavernous, petrosal, and sphenoparietal sinuses.  

 




Option Analysis

❌ Pia mater:
Incorrect: The arrow points to the straight sinus, one of the dural venous sinuses. The walls of the straight sinus are composed of dura mater, not pia mater.
❌ Arachnoid mater:
Incorrect: The arrow points to the straight sinus, one of the dural venous sinuses. The walls of the straight sinus are composed of dura mater, not arachnoid mater.
✅ Dura mater:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Astrocyte foot processes:
Incorrect: The blood-brain barrier comprises astrocyte foot processes, capillary endothelial cells, and the basement membrane. However, the arrow points to the straight sinus, which is formed by the dura mater.
❌ Schwann cells:
Incorrect: Schwann cells are responsible for myelinating axons in the peripheral nervous system. In contrast, the structure indicated by the arrow is the straight sinus, which is within the central nervous system. The walls of this structure are formed by the periosteal and meningeal layers of the dura mater.

questions.text:
A 39-year-old man is involved in a motor vehicle collision. A CT scan of the head is performed and reveals the following:


Image reproduced from Radiopedia

The vessel that is most likely ruptured in this patient enters the skull via which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
This patient’s CT scan reveals lens-shaped hyper-density consistent with an epidural hematoma. Epidural hematomas most commonly arise due to rupture of the middle meningeal artery, which enters the skull via foramen spinosum in the middle cranial fossa.   The nerves and vessels that enter or exit the skull via the different structures are summarized below:



Option Analysis

❌ Foramen ovale:
Incorrect: The mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve (CN V3) exits the skull via foramen ovale in the middle cranial fossa. In contrast, this patient has an epidural hematoma, which is most commonly caused by a tear in the middle meningeal artery. The middle meningeal artery enters the skull via the foramen spinosum. 
❌ Foramen rotundum:
Incorrect: The foramen rotundum carries CN V2 (maxillary division of CN V). CN V2 innervates the skin around the maxillary sinus (around the nose). In contrast, this patient has an epidural hematoma, which is most commonly caused by a tear in the middle meningeal artery. The middle meningeal artery enters the skull via the foramen spinosum. 
❌ Hypoglossal canal:
Incorrect: The hypoglossal canal is the site where the hypoglossal nerve leaves the cranial cavity. The hypoglossal nerve (XII) is responsible for tongue movement, and deficits in this nerve can cause dysarthria. 
❌ Internal auditory meatus:
Incorrect: The internal auditory meatus is the site at which both the facial nerve and the vestibulocochlear nerve leave the cranial cavity. The facial nerve (VII) controls facial movement, lacrimation, salivation, and taste from the anterior 2/3 of the tongue. The vestibulocochlear nerve (VIII) controls balance and hearing. 
✅ Foramen spinosum:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A researcher is studying human spinal cord anatomy. She identifies a tract that helps relay sensations, including vibration, proprioception, and fine touch. Which of the following best characterizes the pathway taken by this tract?

choices.text: Location of Synapse Between First and Second-Order NeuronsSite of DecussationPosterior horn of spinal cordAnterior white commissure
Location of Synapse Between First and Second-Order NeuronsSite of DecussationNucleus gracilisMedulla oblongata
Location of Synapse Between First and Second-Order Neurons   Site of DecussationAnterior horn of spinal cord   Medulla oblongata
Location of Synapse Between First and Second-Order Neurons   Site of Decussation   Posterior horn of spinal cord   Superior cerebellar peduncle
Location of Synapse Between First and Second-Order Neurons   Site of Decussation   Nucleus gracilis   Superior cerebellar peduncle

questions.solution:
The dorsal column medial lemniscus (DCML) tract transmits sensations including vibration, proprioception, two-point discrimination, and soft touch to the brain. First-order neurons of the DCML tract enter the spinal cord via the dorsal root. Afterward, the neurons ascend via the ipsilateral dorsal columns, synapse with second-order neurons in the nucleus gracilis and cuneatus of the medulla, and then decussate (crossover) into the contralateral medulla. The second-order neurons synapse with the third-order neuron in the thalamus. The third-order neurons then travel to the cerebral cortex, where they synapse with fourth-order neurons.

Another important ascending pathway is the spinothalamic tract, which transmits sensations including crude touch, pain, pressure, and temperature to the brain. As with the DCML tract, first-order neurons in the spinothalamic tract enter the spinal cord via the dorsal root. The first-order neurons ascend ipsilaterally for 1-2 spinal segments, synapse with second-order neurons in the posterior horn of the spinal cord, and then decussate in the anterior white commissure. Afterward, the neurons ascend via the contralateral anterior or lateral spinal cord to reach the thalamus. As with the DCML tract, third-order neurons in the spinothalamic tract then travel to the cerebral cortex, where they synapse with fourth-order neurons.  



Option Analysis

❌ Location of Synapse Between First and Second-Order NeuronsSite of DecussationPosterior horn of spinal cordAnterior white commissure:
Incorrect: The first-order neuron in the spinothalamic tract synapses with the second-order neuron at the posterior horn of the spinal cord. Afterward, the second-order neuron decussates at the anterior white commissure and travels upwards towards the thalamus and sensory cortex. However, the spinothalamic tract transmits crude touch, pain, pressure, and temperature sensations.   
✅ Location of Synapse Between First and Second-Order NeuronsSite of DecussationNucleus gracilisMedulla oblongata:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Location of Synapse Between First and Second-Order Neurons   Site of DecussationAnterior horn of spinal cord   Medulla oblongata  :
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the corticospinal tract, which is a descending tract that helps regulate voluntary movements of the trunk and extremities. It is not involved in relaying sensory information to the brain.   
❌ Location of Synapse Between First and Second-Order Neurons   Site of Decussation   Posterior horn of spinal cord   Superior cerebellar peduncle  :
Incorrect: The first-order neuron in the spinocerebellar tract synapses with the second-order neuron in the posterior horn of the spinal cord. Afterward, the neurons either decussate immediately and become part of the ventral spinocerebellar tract (which later decussates again in the superior cerebellar peduncle) or ascend ipsilaterally as the dorsal spinocerebellar tract. However, the spinocerebellar tract transmits unconscious proprioceptive information and is not involved in relaying sensations of vibration or touch.   
❌ Location of Synapse Between First and Second-Order Neurons   Site of Decussation   Nucleus gracilis   Superior cerebellar peduncle  :
Incorrect: The dorsal column medial lemniscus (DCML) tract is responsible for relaying sensations including vibration, proprioception, and soft touch to the brain. While the synapse between the first-order and second-order neurons of the DCML tract is within the nucleus gracilis and cuneatus, decussation occurs at the medulla (as opposed to the superior cerebellar peduncle).

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents to the physician to evaluate right shoulder weakness, which has been ongoing for three months. The symptom has limited her daily activities, such as brushing her hair. Vital signs are within normal limits. The patient has weakness abducting the right shoulder above 90 degrees on physical examination. In addition, there is atrophy of the right trapezius muscle. The findings are concerning for a nerve injury. Through which of the following mechanisms did this nerve injury likely occur?

choices.text: Lymph node biopsy in the posterior cervical triangle.
Thyroidectomy with superior thyroid artery dissection
Thyroidectomy with inferior thyroid artery dissection

questions.solution:
The spinal accessory nerve, or cranial nerve XI, consists of a spinal portion originating from the ventral horns of the upper four cervical segments of the spinal cord which is then joined by accessory components that arise from the nucleus accumbens of the medulla oblongata.  

These two components form the eleventh cranial nerve, and together, they exit the skull through the jugular foramen. The spinal accessory nerve then courses below the posterior belly of the digastric and upper end of the sternocleidomastoid muscle (SCM). It emerges from the posterior border of the SCM and crosses the posterior triangle before entering the trapezius. Recall, the posterior triangle of the neck is bounded inferiorly by the middle one-third of the clavicle, anteriorly by the posterior border of the sternocleidomastoid, and posteriorly by the anterior border of the trapezius.  

Cranial nerve XI is particularly susceptible to injury as it courses through the posterior triangle of the neck. Injury is most commonly caused by iatrogenic etiologies (e.g., lymph node biopsy, neck dissection) but can also be caused by trauma or tumors.  

Injury to the spinal accessory nerve can lead to paralysis of both the trapezius and sternocleidomastoid muscles. Clinical symptoms include shoulder pain, limited abduction of the shoulder beyond 90 degrees, and shoulder drop. These symptoms may impact an individual’s ability to complete daily tasks, such as combing one’s hair.  



Option Analysis

✅ Lymph node biopsy in the posterior cervical triangle. :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Thyroidectomy with superior thyroid artery dissection :
Incorrect: The external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve can be injured during thyroidectomies due to its proximity with the superior thyroid artery. Patients with this nerve injury may notice changes in voice quality but would not typically experience difficulty abducting the shoulder.   
❌ Thyroidectomy with inferior thyroid artery dissection :
Incorrect: The recurrent laryngeal nerve is susceptible to injury during dissection of the inferior thyroid artery. Patients with recurrent laryngeal nerve injury may experience hoarseness of the voice but not difficulty abducting the shoulder. 
❌ Left atrial enlargement:
Incorrect: Left atrial enlargement can compress the recurrent laryngeal nerve, not the spinal accessory nerve. 
❌ Medial medullary syndrome :
Incorrect: Medial medullary syndrome is caused by occlusion of the medullary branch of the vertebral artery. It results in a lower motor neuron hypoglossal nerve injury in addition to contralateral hemiparesis and contralateral loss of proprioception and tactile discrimination.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman notices the left side of her face does not move when she tries to smile. She has also experienced difficulty closing her left eye. The cranial nerve affected in this patient originates from which of the following regions of the central nervous system?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has paralysis of the facial nerve (CN VII). The nucleus of CN VII is located in the pons. The cranial nerve nuclei are located in the tegmentum portion of the brain stem (between dorsal and ventral portions). Their locations are as follows:  

  •  Midbrain - nuclei of CN III, IV 
  •  Pons - nuclei of CN V, VI, VII, VIII 
  •  Medulla - nuclei of CN IX, X, XII 
  •  Spinal cord - nucleus of CN XI 

Option Analysis

❌ Medulla  :
Incorrect: The nuclei of cranial nerves IX, X and XII are found in the medulla. In contrast, this patient has dysfunction of the facial nerve (CN VII).  
✅ Pons  :
Correct: See Main Examination.  
❌ Midbrain  :
Incorrect: The nuclei of CN III and IV are found in the midbrain. In contrast, this patient has dysfunction of the facial nerve (CN VII).  
❌ Spinal cord  :
Incorrect: The nucleus of CN XI is found in the spinal cord. In contrast, this patient has dysfunction of the facial nerve (CN VII).  
❌ Diencephalon:
Incorrect: CN II originates as an evagination of the diencephalon. In contrast, this patient has dysfunction of the facial nerve (CN VII).

questions.text:
An axial view of the cerebellum is shown below:


Which of the following answer choices correctly identifies the structure represented by each number?
questions.solution:
The cerebellum is a structure located within the posterior cranial fossa. It coordinates movements, controls posture, balance, and fine motor movements, and is involved in motor learning. Within the deep white matter of the cerebellum are four nuclei, which are made up of clusters of neuronal cell bodies. The nuclei, from lateral to medial, are the dentate, emboliform, globus, and fastigial nucleus. Of note, the emboliform and globus nuclei are collectively termed the interposed nucleus.  

Information from the different functional regions that make up the cerebellar cortex are transmitted to the nuclei. The lateral zone transmits to the dentate nucleus, the intermediate zone transmits to the emboliform and globus nuclei, and the medial zone to the fastigial nucleus. Afterwards, information from the cerebellar nuclei leaves via the cerebellar peduncles and is sent to various structures including the midbrain, cerebral cortex, and spinal cord.  

Option Analysis

❌  Structure 1  Structure 2  Structure 3  Structure 4  Fastigial nucleus  Globus nucleus  Emboliform nucleus  Dentate nucleus  :
Incorrect: The four cerebellar nuclei, from lateral to medial, are the dentate, emboliform, globus, and fastigial nuclei. As a result, structure one would correspond to the dentate nucleus, structure two the emboliform nucleus, structure three the globus nucleus, and structure four the fastigial nucleus.
✅  Structure 1  Structure 2  Structure 3  Structure 4  Dentate nucleus  Emboliform nucleus  Globus nucleus  Fastigial nucleus  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌  Structure 1  Structure 2  Structure 3  Structure 4  Emboliform nucleus  Dentate nucleus  Globus nucleus  Fastigial nucleus  :
Incorrect: The four cerebellar nuclei, from lateral to medial, are the dentate, emboliform, globus, and fastigial nuclei. As a result, structure one would correspond to the dentate nucleus, structure two the emboliform nucleus, structure three the globus nucleus, and structure four the fastigial nucleus.
❌  Structure 1  Structure 2  Structure 3 Structure 4  Lateral zone  Intermediate zone  Anterior zone  Medial zone  :
Incorrect: The three functional zones of the cerebellum are the lateral, intermediate, and medial zones. These zones send signals to the emboliform nucleus, interposed nucleus (the collective term for the emboliform and globus nucleus), and the fastigial nucleus, respectively. The numbered structures in the above image correspond to the nuclei, not the functional zones.
❌  Structure 1  Structure 2 Structure 3  Structure 4  Lateral zone  Intermediate zone  Paravermal zone  Vermal zone  :
Incorrect: The three functional zones of the cerebellum are the lateral, intermediate, and medial zones. These zones send signals to the emboliform nucleus, interposed nucleus (the collective term for the emboliform and globus nucleus), and the fastigial nucleus, respectively. The numbered structures in the above image correspond to the nuclei, not the functional zones.

questions.text: A study was conducted to determine the different cell types and their functions in the central nervous system. One cell was identified using a special stain called glial fibrillary acid proteins (GFAP). These cells were found to have long foot processes. Which of the following is a function of the cell described?

choices.text: Production of myelin sheath in the central nervous system.

questions.solution:
The cells described in the question are most likely Astrocytes. Astrocytes are glial cells that are found in the grey matter of the central nervous system. Astrocytes have long foot processes, and they produce a protein called glial fibrillary acid proteins (GFAP), which can be used to immunostain astrocytes.  

The astrocytes are the most abundant glial cells in the central nervous system. The foot processes of the astrocytes contribute to the blood-brain barrier. Also, astrocytes are responsible for removing and recycling excess neurotransmitters. Finally, astrocytes are involved in the regeneration and repair after neuronal injury.  


Option Analysis

✅ Contribute to the blood-brain barrier  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Production of cerebrospinal fluid  :
Incorrect: Ependymal cells produce cerebrospinal fluid, and these cells line the ventricles. However, it does not stain with GFAP.  
❌ Production of myelin sheath in the central nervous system.  :
Incorrect: Oligodendrocytes are responsible for myelin sheath formation in the central nervous system. However, they do not stain with GFAP.  
❌ Transmission of nerve impulses  :
Incorrect: Neurons are responsible for transmitting nerve impulses. They do not stain with GFAP.  
❌ Phagocytosis:
Incorrect: Microglial cells are phagocytosing cells of the central nervous system. These cells do not stain with GFAP.

questions.text: A segment of a peripheral nerve is taken and examined under the microscope. In the segment, the axons, nerve fascicles, endoneurium, perineurium, and epineurium were identified. Which of the following is true regarding these structures?

choices.text: Blood vessels within the nerves are found in the epineurium
The epineurium surrounds a single nerve fascicle
The endoneurium surrounds a single nerve fascicle containing many nerve fibers.
Blood vessels within the nerves are found in the endoneurium
Blood vessels within the nerves are found in the perineurium

questions.solution:
Peripheral nerves comprise at least one bundle of nerve fibers called the fascicle, which contains many axons. The perineurium is a layer of connective tissue that surrounds each fascicle. This perineurium contributes to the blood-nerve barrier.  


Each nerve fiber inside the nerve fascicle is surrounded by a thin layer of connective tissue called the endoneurium. These nerve fibers surrounded by the endoneurium are made of axons (centrally located) and Schwann cells.  


Finally, the epineurium is a dense connective tissue layer that surrounds the entire nerve and contains many fascicles. The epineurium also extends between the fascicles and holds them together. Blood vessels within the nerve are found in the epineurium.


Option Analysis

✅ Blood vessels within the nerves are found in the epineurium  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ The epineurium surrounds a single nerve fascicle  :
Incorrect: The perineurium surrounds a single nerve fascicle, which is made of a group of axons. The epineurium surrounds a group of nerve fascicles.  
❌ The endoneurium surrounds a single nerve fascicle containing many nerve fibers.  :
Incorrect: The endoneurium surrounds only one nerve fiber within the nerve fascicle. On the other hand, the perineurium surrounds a nerve fascicle.  
❌ Blood vessels within the nerves are found in the endoneurium  :
Incorrect: The blood vessels within the nerves are found in the epineurium.  
❌ Blood vessels within the nerves are found in the perineurium  :
Incorrect: The blood vessels within the nerves are found in the epineurium

questions.text: A researcher is studying the pathological changes seen in Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS). According to the study, the nerve terminals in the peripheral nervous system lose their myelin sheath in GBS, leading to the disease manifestations. This myelin sheath is produced by which of the following cells in the peripheral nervous system?
questions.solution:
Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS) is a demyelinating disorder that affects nerves in the peripheral nervous system (PNS). The PNS contains all the nerves and the ganglia outside the central nervous system (CNS), i.e., the brain and spinal cord. The nerves of the PNS have many axons that convey signals from the CNS to the organs.  

Myelin is an insulating layer that wraps around the CNS and the PNS axons. It functions as an insulator and increases signal transmission speed by axons. Myelin production in the CNS is by oligodendrocytes, which are abundant in the white matter of the CNS. On the other hand, Schwann cells are responsible for myelinating axons in the PNS.  

Option Analysis

✅ Schwann cells  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Oligodendrocytes:
Incorrect: Oligodendrocytes are responsible for myelinating nerve axons in the central nervous system, not the peripheral nervous system.
❌ Fibroblasts:
Incorrect: Fibroblasts found in the nerves cannot produce myelin, and their function is unknown.  
❌ Microglial cells  :
Incorrect: Microglial cells are glial cells found in the central nervous system only, and they function as phagocytosing cells. They are incapable of producing myelin.  
❌ Astrocytes:
Incorrect: Astrocytes are only found in the central nervous system. They regulate blood flow, transfer mitochondria to neurons, and supply the building blocks of neurotransmitters, which fuel neuronal metabolism. However, they do not produce myelin.

questions.text: A segment of the spinal cord is examined under microscopy. In the segment, the portion to the periphery was identified to be the white matter. Which of the following is true about white matter?

choices.text: It contains axons with abundant myelin sheath
It contains the cell bodies of the neurons in the central nervous system
Most of the glial cells are found in the white matter
Myelination of the axons is done by Schwann cells
It is only found in the spinal cord in the central nervous system

questions.solution:
The central nervous system comprises the cerebrum, cerebellum, brainstem, and spinal cord. The primary cells found in the CNS are neurons and non-neuronal cells (glial cells).  

The cerebrum, cerebellum, and spinal cord are divided into gray and white matters, which were made by their appearance in gross and microscopic examination. The white matter got its name from its lighter appearance because it is made of axons and abundant myelin sheath, and the myelin sheath disappears, leaving a white space. On the other hand, the gray matter comprises the neuronal cell bodies, its dendrites, and the glial cells (e.g., oligodendrocytes, astrocytes, microglial cells). The glial cells are mainly found in gray matter.  

The gray matter is found in the outermost portion of the cerebellum and cerebrum, while the white matter is found deep. The opposite is true in the spinal cord, where the white matter is on the periphery, and the gray matter is located in the center of the spinal cord.  


Option Analysis

✅ It contains axons with abundant myelin sheath  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ It contains the cell bodies of the neurons in the central nervous system  :
Incorrect: The cell bodies in the central nervous system are found in the gray matter, while the white matter contains the axons of these neurons.  
❌ Most of the glial cells are found in the white matter  :
Incorrect: Glial cells are mainly found in the gray matter of the central nervous system, not the white matter.  
❌ Myelination of the axons is done by Schwann cells  :
Incorrect: Schwann cells are responsible for myelination of the peripheral nervous system neurons, while central nervous system neurons and nerve terminals (including axons in the white matter) are myelinated by the oligodendrocytes.  
❌ It is only found in the spinal cord in the central nervous system  :
Incorrect: The white matter is found in the spinal cord, the cerebrum, and the cerebellum.
